title: At the Intersection of Data Science and Language

author: Kathleen McKeown, Department of Computer Science, Columbia University

Information.

So for this we used a corpus of 19th century novels.
We had 60 novels and they were selected by the comparative literature professor on our team to represent different genres over that period of time.
The work was a collaboration between computer science and comparative literature and we were looking to see whether we could provide evidence for or against literary theory.
And we did this through social network extraction from the literature.
So from in our corpus for each novel we built a network based on conversation within the novel.
Our method with based on quoted speech, we automatically identify who talks to whom and then we extracted features of the graph that we could use to evaluate the hypothesis.

So one of the hypothesis that we looked at was that larger conversational novels with more people tend to be less connected, so this was associated with the move from novels like Jane Austen and the country into novels by Dickens in the city where there were a much larger group of people and cities were industrialized and therefore less friendly.
So the theory was that these larger conversational networks with more people.
Tend to be less connected.
We have two theorists here.
Franco Moretti, who says at 10 or 20 characters.

It's possible to include distant and openly hostile groups, and Terry Eagleton, who said most of our encounters consist of seen rather than speaking, glimpsing each other as objects rather than conversing as fellow subjects.
So our question was, can we show empirically that conversational networks with fewer people?
Are more closely connected.
To construct the social network we had nodes which represented people who said something and we were able to do this task called quote Attribution with 83% accuracy.
We set edges equal to people who are talking to each other and we use quote adjacency as a heuristic for detecting conversations.
The edge weight was set to the share of detected conversation over the novel an we could detect conversation with 95% precision, but we only got about 51% of the conversations.

We looked at the impact of network size, so according to our theory we would expect that as the number of named characters increases, we would get the same or less total speech an we found this to be true.
The number normalized number of quotes was flat.
We would expect to have a less lopsided distribution of quotes among speakers, and we found this to be true.
The share of quotes by the top three speakers decreases.
As the number of named and characters increases, we would expect to find lower density that is fewer conversational partners as a percentage of the population, and we found this not to be true.
Larger networks are more connected.
We would expect to find the same or fewer cliques, and we found this also not to be true.
The three clique rate increases larger networks formed cliques more often.
So we thought, well, maybe we should be looking at speakers, not just name characters, and so we would expect as the number of speakers increases, we would expect to see less overall dialogue.
This quote, glimpsing rather than speaking.
But we found this not to be true.
Larger networks are more talkative.
We would also expect lower density that is in larger networks people speak to more of their neighbors.
And we found this not to be true, that is, that in larger networks people know more if their neighbors, whereas the opposite should be true.

And then finally, if we look at a first person narrative, so this is Dickens David Copperfield, the eye is very dominant and there are much fewer conversations between the other characters.

Well, we've learned that high precision conversational networks can be extracted from literature, and we think the time is right for the natural language field to be exploring analysis of fiction.

And we did this through social network extraction from the literature.
